titleStmt.title: Poem of Pictures
a machine readable transcription

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Edward Grier notes that the poem proposed here is likely related to both "Pictures," a lengthy manuscript poem held at the Beinecke Library at Yale University that was probably written in the mid- to late-1850s, and "Poem of Salutation," first published in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass and later retitled "Salut au Monde!" Therefore, the date of this manuscript is likely before 1855.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Leaves of Grass, [ca. 1855–1856], AMs, 12 fragments on 7 leaves
bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

revisionDesc.change: converted from P4 to P5, checked

work.p: This manuscript was probably early notes toward the manuscript poem "Pictures," first published posthumously in 1925. That poem includes the following lines: "And here again, this picture tells a story of the Olympic games, / See you, the chariot races? See you, the boxers boxing, and the runners running?" and "This, again, is a Spanish bull-fight—see, the animal with bent head, fiercely advancing" (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts, ed. Edward F. Grier [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 4:1298–1300).
This note may relate to the images described in "Poem of Salutation," first published in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass and later retitled "Salut au Monde!"

div1.note: Picture of one of the Greek games—wrestling, or the chariot-race, or running.
div1.ab: Each verse presenting a picture of some characteristic scene, event, group, or personage—old or new, other countries or our own country.—
